Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I glanced at my phone as I rinsed the thick conditioner from my client’s hair, the screen lighting up with a message from my stepmom: “Haven’t heard from you this weekend. Everything okay?” Guilt pricked at me. She and Dad always said it meant a lot to get a quick check-in, especially since I moved out. I’d promised to text every weekend, but work had been nonstop. Now, my client’s hair was a mess of knots, the product buildup so dense my comb barely moved. She was already anxious about the time, and I knew I’d have to spend extra minutes detangling before I could even think about cutting. My manager expected me to keep appointments on schedule, but I couldn’t rush this without risking damage. My phone buzzed again. I felt torn—if I paused to text my stepmom, I’d fall further behind, but if I ignored her, I’d be letting down my family. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my attention, and I stood there, hands dripping, heart racing, caught between the two worlds that needed me.
